_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Energy Transfer LP
Benedum Gas Plant
Midkiff, Texas

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
FOR 
THE RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN (RMPlan)

Introduction and Policies
Energy Transfer LP is committed to managing all operations in a manner that protects the environment and the health and safety of employees, customers, contractors and the public while complying with applicable laws and regulations.  Energy Transfers management philosophy goals are achieved through the implementation of the Environmental, Health, and Safety Management Systems, by the personal commitments of employees and contractors, and by open communication with employees, customers, neighbors, and regulators. 
The purpose of this Risk Management Plan (RMP) is to provide information about operations at the facility, programs to prevent accidental chemical releases, emergency planning and response activities in the event an accidental release should occur, the five-year accident history of the facility, and continuous improvement efforts to improve safety at the facility.
Non-Responding Stationary Source and Regulated Substances
Energy Transfer owns and operates a natural gas processing plant located near Midkiff, Texas.  The Benedum Gas Plant compresses and treats natural gas to produce residue gas (methane) and natural gas liquids (NGL).  After processing, the residue gas and NGL exit the plant via product pipelines. 
Gas enters the plant through either a high- or low-pressure inlet system.  Low-pressure gas is compressed and sent through amine treatment to remove hydrogen sulfide and carbon dioxide; the resulting waste gas is burned off using a flare.  Amine-treated gas is then mixed with the high-pressure inlet gas and flows through a molecular sieve gas dehydrator to remove water.  The gas then flows to a cryogenic unit that separates out NGL, which leaves the Benedum Gas Plant via pipeline.  The remaining gas is compressed and leaves the plant via pipeline. 
Field (unstabilized) condensate is delivered to the Benedum Gas Pl

ant via tank truck and stored in two roof storage tanks.  Emissions that occur during unloading are controlled by a dedicated tank farm flare.  Field condensate is fed into a gun-barrel tank for initial three-phase separation.  Gas produced from this separation is sent to a vapor recovery unit and then to the plants low-pressure inlet system.  Pre-stabilized condensate flows to a heater treater before being stored in a roof storage tank.  Water produced at the Benedum Gas Plant is routed and stored in a fixed roof storage tank.  The fixed-roof storage tanks are periodically emptied via tank truck load-out.  
The RMP flammable substances and mixtures stored or processed at the facility are the flammable mixture comprised of methane, ethane, propane, isobutane, butane, isopentane, and pentane, which is being processed through the plant; as well as propane, which is used as refrigerant in the cryogenic process. There are no toxic substances present at the facility in amounts greater than threshold quantity.  
Energy Transfer has determined that the gas plant should be considered one process under the RMP rule.  This facility has one process (as defined by the regulation) consisting of a flammable mixture and propane.  Although the systems containing the flammable mixture and the propane are not interconnected, an incident in one of the systems could trigger a release in the other system, therefore, the two systems should be considered one process (see definition of process at 40 CFR 68.3). 
Energy Transfer has determined that Benedum Gas Plant is classified as a Program Level 3 facility under the RMP regulation because the nearest public receptor is within the worst-case scenario flammable endpoint radius and the facility is subject to the OSHA Process Safety Management Standard. 
Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies
The accidental release prevention and emergency planning and response programs in place at the facility include:
-	Operating i

n compliance with required environmental permits and regulations. 
-	Operating and maintaining assets in such a manner that unintentional releases are minimized.
-	Operating and maintaining assets in such a manner that the small releases associated with normal operation and maintenance will be minimized to the extent possible.
-	Correcting non-compliance found by regular audits of the facility, operator training and intervention.
Prevention Program
The Benedum Gas Plant is operating under a prevention program that involves identifying and taking steps to avoid potential accidental chemical releases.  A few examples of the prevention features implemented at this facility include: 
-	Providing overpressure relief valves on pressurized vessels.
-	Providing level transmitters and alarms on vessels to help prevent overfilling.
-	Minimizing the possibility of an interruption in the combustion of hydrocarbon vapors by having a continuous flare.
-	Providing automated and manual valves to isolate portions of the process.
-	Installing hydrocarbon gas detectors throughout the gas plant to alarm personnel of a possible explosive environment.
-	Installing fire eye detectors throughout the gas plant to alarm personnel of a possible fire.
-	Installing security lighting to facilitate observation of the entire facility.
-	Minimizing the possibility of emergencies by manning the facility 24/7/365.
-	Providing an evacuation alarm system in order to safely evacuate personnel from the facility.
-	Conducting periodic operational rounds to ensure problems are detected and corrected in a timely manner.
	Five-Year Accident History
	No incident resulting in onsite injuries, death or significant property damage or known offsite impacts (e.g. death, injury, property damage, shelter in place, evacuation, or environmental damage) from the accidental release of a regulated substance has occurred at the facility within the last five years.
	Emergency Planning and Response Program
	The facility wil

l conduct emergency response preparedness activities and coordinate any emergency response actions necessary with the Upton County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and the Upton County Volunteer Fire Department.  Also included in emergency response for the facility will be the Upton County Sheriffs Department.  The Plant Management is responsible for coordinating the emergency actions when an incident occurs within the facility.  An emergency response program is in place at the facility which has been coordinated with local officials.  The Benedum Gas Plant is designated as a non-responding stationary source.  The emergency planning and response program provides the essential information for effectively protecting workers, the public, and the environment during emergency situations.  
	Continuous Safety Improvement Efforts
	Energy Transfers Environmental, Health, and Safety Management System forms the framework for continuous safety improvement.  Some of the key components are: 
-	The Management of Change provisions ensure that the potential safety and health impacts of any change made to process chemicals, technology, or equipment are considered.
-	The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) review serves as a tool to ensure timely evaluation of potential process hazards and verification of safeguards, thereby leading to continual improvements in process safety and safe work practices.
-	The Mechanical Integrity program ensures that process equipment and instrumentation are designed, constructed, installed and maintained to minimize the risk of hazardous releases, thereby serving as an integral part of the safety program.
-	Incident Investigation procedures are in place to ensure that corrective and/or preventative measures are taken, as applicable, following an incident.  This ensures that process design, operating equipment, and operating and maintenance safe work practices are evaluated to determine changes needed to prevent recurrence of an incident.
-	Interna

l and third-party compliance audits will ensure that the level of safety protection at the facility is periodically evaluated for improvements with any action items tracked to completion.
-	An annual dialogue with the Upton County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and the Upton County Volunteer Fire Department will ensure a readiness to respond to potential emergencies, as well as a means to implement improvements as the need develops.
